title: universal credit five week wait could be slashed amber rudd hints
story: When asked about whether she would cut the wait for new claimants, the DWP boss said she was looking at what we can do to get cash into peoples hands earlier.It comes after she promised to fix problems with the flagship benefits system and accepted there were areas in which it wasnt working.She told the BBC today that the biggest problem is getting cash into peoples hands as soon as they need it.Advance payments are available for Brits who cant wait five weeks for money, but that has to be paid back immediately out of their first UC sum.Ms Rudd said her department would make it clear to people they can get that upfront as soon as they apply and then pay it back over  months.On a damning report by a UN representative earlier this week, she promised to look at the concerns with women and single mums in particular.But she blasted the findings as being too political and implying the system was there to negatively impact Brits.The aim is to help people when they need it, and help them into work, she told Radio s Today programme.Our motives are to be efficient and compassionate.Ministers have already announced they will give an extra two weeks of several benefits to people on Universal Credit in future - but this wont come in until .At the moment people moving onto the new system get an extra two weeks of just housing benefit to help them cope with the switch.Ms Rudd insisted: The main message I want to give is that Universal Credit is a force for good and we will see how we can fix it.The new benefits system has been beset with issues since it first began being rolled out in .One chippy owner said yesterday the new system was pushing Brits AWAY from work as people couldnt figure out whether they would be better off or not.And earlier this week one desperate mum told how she was forced into sex work to get money for food after waiting for her first payment.One in six Brits still arent getting their first sum on time, the latest Universal Credit stats showed.

title: meghan markle visit grenfell tower community kitchen
story: Keen chef Meghan, , dropped in to visit the Hubb Community Kitchen in West London after helping them write a cookbook in the wake of the blaze.Today she saw how proceeds from the book were being spent as she visited the newly-renovated kitchen to help cook  meals for the local community.She beamed as she cradled her baby bump during the secret visit - which was not publicised beforehand.The Duchess, who wore a burgundy dress and coat by Club Monaco, showed off her cooking skills after being greeted with huge smiles and hugs on Wednesday morning.Later she drank ginger tea as she spoke to some of the women - telling them: Im so proud of you. title: facebook mark zuckerberg refuses resign russia us election
story: Zuckerberg - and the company he founded - have been under pressure amid claims Facebook attempted to ignore and conceal Kremlin efforts to interfere with the social media site.In an interview with CNN, he was askedhe would step down as chairman, a role he holds alongside that of chief executive.He replied thats not the plan before adding I am currently not thinking that makes sense.But he admitted: In  there’s no doubt that we missed something really important.The Russian effort to try to have these co-ordinated information operations on Facebook and also on the internet more broadly, was not something we were expecting.Elections are always high security events and we were expecting cyberattacks and we found them.The Russians were trying to hack into specic accounts and we told the people, and we told the FBI, and all that.But we weren’t on top of these co-ordinated information operations. So we’ve spent a lot of the last couple of years now building up our systems and strengthening them to address this.Earlier this year it was reported workers at a Russian troll factory are paid almost £ a week to churn out fake news on Facebook and Twitter.Facebook has admitted that  million American users were served content from Russia-linked propaganda sites during the  presidential campaign.Facebooks senior management have been renewed scrutiny after a New York Times report claimed it had hired a PR firm to discredit critics of the social network by linking their funding to philanthropist George Soros.It follows the Cambridge Analytica scandal earlier this year, and a high-profile data breach reported in September.Mr Zuckerberg also said he hoped to continue working with chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg, who has also been under pressure.Sheryl is a really important part of this company and is leading a lot of the efforts to address a lot of the biggest issues that we have, and shes been an important partner for me for  years and Im really proud of the work that weve done together, said Zuckerberg.I hope that we work together for decades more to come.Zuckerberg said the company was keen to work with governments and other organisations to deal with problems such as fake news and election interference because it couldn’t do it all by itself.He acknowledged recent criticism of the company was fair, but was defiant about the work Facebook was doing, saying it gave people a voice.There are always going to be issuesyoure serving a community of more than two billion people, he said.Theres going to be someone who is posting something that is problematic, that gets through the systems that we have in place, no matter how advanced the systems are.

title: labour jeremy corbyn power theresa may brexit
story: The Labour leaders right-hand man said the Queen would have a duty to make Mr Corbyn Prime MinisterTheresa Mays Brexit struggles continue.John McDonnell insisted Labour would be able to enter Government even without a mandate from the British public.He pointed to the DUP rebellion this week which has stopped the PM winning key Commons votes on the Budget.The Shadow Chancellor said: The test is whether or not Government is losing consistent votes on the issue of the deal itself.“If it is, it is demonstrating as a minority government it hasn’t got the will of House – a majority in the House.“The normal process is the opposition party should be offered the opportunity to seeit can form a Government.He added: If it’s minority Government and they can’t attain a majority in Parliament, usually it is the duty of the Monarch to make the offer to the opposition the opportunity to form a Government.Speaking at a Reuters event in London Mr McDonnell said Labour wants to see a General Election - but admitted its unlikely without the consent of the Tories.Instead he revealed the partys plan to cobble together a shaky coalition to replace Mrs May in case her deal gets shot down by the Commons.He said: Give us the opportunity to take over and seewe can form a Government, a minority but with a majority position in Parliament.Labour would find it almost impossible to command a majority in the Commons.They would need the support of every smaller party - including the fiercely anti-Corbyn DUP - and all independent MPs.That means the Tories and DUP together will always be able to block Labour from taking power, barring a fresh General Election.Mr Corbyns party faced its own Brexit chaos today as a Labour frontbencher came out in support of a second referendum.Shadow Culture Secretary Steve Reed said: Only the people can break the logjam.

title: theresa may brexit plan immigration dominic raab
story: The former Brexit Secretary claimed the fatally flawed withdrawal agreement would lock the UK into free movement for good.He called on fellow Tories to choose hope as he blasted the PM for launching a new round of Project Fear to try and force her deal through.Mr Raab resigned last week after deciding he couldnt support the withdrawal agreement Mrs May agreed with Brussels.Laying out his reasons in the Dailytoday, the ex-minister pointed to the controversial Irish backstop and the additional text outlining the future trade deal between Britain and the EU.He said the trade document takes the customs union-single market regime as the starting point.Mr Raab added: In practice, the backstop would become permanent, or worse, as the EU - arguing the inisibility of the single market - insists that the UK accept some free movement rules as the price of a deal.Once locked into the backstop, the EU would have zero incentive to agree to any alternative approach in subsequent negotiations.Instead of taking back control, we would be giving up even more control over swathes of UK economic and social policy, and forfeiting all hope of an independent global trade policy.Keeping EU free movement rules would stop Britain from deciding which migrants are allowed to move here.The former Brexit Secretary concluded: This is a historic struggle for the heart and soul of our country - between those who believe that managed decline is all we have left, and those of us who believe that this countrys best days lie ahead.Buried beneath the rafts of technical detail, it is a struggle between hope and fear.Mr Raab was replaced by Stephen Barclay when he quit  hours after the Cabinet signed off on Mrs Mays Brexit deal.He insists he still backs the PM - but wants her to ditch her deal and prepare Britain for a No Deal outcome.

title: web creator sir tim berners lee i see a revolution starting right now
story: The awakening for him, as for so many people, came in , with the twin shocks of Brexit and the election of Donald Trump."What happened there was a tipping point," he says.He knew that social media could be used to manipulate people, but for the first time he saw it operating at massive scale."I thought that my responsibility as a web user was to go and find the stuff which I appreciated, which I trusted, but now I think that everyone involved in the web realises the problem is that other people are reading stuff which is complete garbage and theyre believing it, and they vote."He mentions voting. Does that, I ask, mean democracy itself is under threat "Science tells us what to believe are facts," he says. "And democracy relies on facts. So democracy relies on science." Sir Tim sees the core of the problem as the massive centralisation of his originally decentralised web.

story: NewsUN blasts Amber Rudd as she brands Universal Credit tremendous force for goodThe new Work and Pensions Secretary has hailed the six-in-one benefit and dismissed a critical UN report - but its author accuses her of "missing the point"ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsIn her first interview since taking the job today, the Work and Pensions Secretary hailed the benefit as a tremendous force for good "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA United Nations expert has blasted Amber Rudd after the Tory welfare chief dug in her heels to defend the disastrous rollout of Universal Credit. In her first interview since taking the job today, the Work and Pensions Secretary hailed the benefit as a tremendous force for good.She also repeated her criticism of a very political report that savaged welfare cuts by the UN special rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights.That UN expert, Philip Alston, found punitive, mean-spirited and often callous welfare cuts had inflicted great misery on the British people. Last night he hit back at Ms Rudd, saying she had missed the point.  Mr Alston told : Alston, the UN special rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights, told the : “I think that dismissing a report that is full of statistics and first-hand testimony on the grounds that the minister didn’t appreciate the tone of the report rather misses the point. I remain hopeful that Amber Rudd might actually take some of the steps needed to address the worst aspects of the existing approach. Ms Rudd first criticised the UN report in her first appearance as Work and Pensions Secretary in the House of Commons. Today she added it was implying it was an effort to make some sort of social engineering which is detrimental to people. She promised to look at particular elements raised in the report. But despite Tory George Osborne slashing billions from benefits she claimed: What I resent about his approach is the motives he attributes to us. The motives are wrong.  Ms Rudd admitted there had been problems with Universal Credit including soaring use of food banks adding: I’m looking at what we can do to get cash into people’s hands earlier. The Tory also hinted at a shake-up to the policy of paying people monthly, saying: I think that’s something I should look at and I will.But she did not commit to halt the rollout of the benefit, which some campaigners now say needs to be scrapped.She said UC is more generous than the old system, telling the BBC: This is going to be dferent and better.

story: NewsInstagram copycat stalker accused of mimicking students posts committed NO crimeDundee University student Chloe Cowan says a woman using the name Honey Basra copied dozens of her photosShareCommentsByMark McGivernJames MoncurChris kitching:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video creepy-classmate-copies-students-social-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA law student who claims her Instagram posts were copied by a stranger for two years was told by police that no crime was committed, it is claimed. Linzi had written a Facebook post about the alleged copycat to warn others about the dangers of social media. She wrote: “My sister Chloe is at Dundee university and another girl living in Dundeehas been reenacting her le on Instagram for almost  years. “This girls behaviour is to the extreme of reenacting videos of a photo album that Chloe posted of my dad who past away .  “This girl doesn’t follow my sister on social media and had made a fake account.” Linzi, from Glasgow, accused the woman of stalking her sister. She wrote: “ behaviour is not OK and I just wanted this out in the open for people to be aware of just how scary social media can be. “My sister should not have to hide away in worry of her every move being stalked by another girl.” The strangers Instagram account has since been deleted.has been unable to contact the person behind it. title: kids not ready lose mummy
story: NewsHeartbroken dad says children arent ready to lose mummy with terminal cancerLeanne Barret, , from Derby, was diagnosed with lung cancer while pregnant and her family are raising money for le-prolonging treatmentShareCommentsByElaine McCahillNathan Standley:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsA womans children arent ready to lose their mummy after she was diagnosed with lung cancer while pregnant "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young dad told has told of how his young children arent ready to lose their mummy after his we was diagnosed with cancer while pregnant. Jamie Barretts we Leanne was diagnosed with stage four lung cancer in October after a growth the size of a pea grew into a five-centimetre mass on her left lung. Leanne, , gave birth to their baby boy  weeks prematurely after doctors decided the growth hormones caused by her pregnancy were stopping her from responding to treatment. The couple are now raising funds for le-prolonging treatment as Jamie, , said: Im not ready to lose my we and my kids arent ready to lose their mummy. After her diagnosis, Leanne decided to continue with the pregnancy and endured a series of agonising investigative procedures throughout, reports Derbyshire Live.   Leanne had been given the option of an abortion but decided against it as she had bonded with her unborn child, Jamie said. The couple were later told they were having a baby boy after losing his unborn twin before the -week scan. But doctors were forced to deliver the baby early as Leanne needed further treatment. Their baby boy, Beau Hudson Barrett, was born via Caesarean section atThe Royal Derby Hospital on November , weighing just lb oz. The couple are also parents to daughter India-Lily. Beau remains in neo-natal intensive care but his dad Jamie says he is coping well. He said: Hes doing well, hes fighting and hes improved day by day. The team down there have been absolutely brilliant.   Jamie, from Rolleston, who is thecaptain of Gresley FC, said of his daughter: Were trying to keep her away from all this. She knows that her mummys been poorly but she thinks that its just to do with the pregnancy. Jamie and Leanne have been together for  years and Leanne enjoyed a happy, healthy and active pregnancy in  when their first child, India-Lily, was born. The couple were married in , but shortly afterwards Jamie said Leanne developed what looked like a pimple on her nose which they got checked once it continued to grow. Doctors said this was likely a symptom of an auto-immune disease called Sarcoidosis and sent her for aseries of CT scans and X-rays. Further scans on her chest showed that Leanne had a mass of enlarged lymphnodes in her chest, which later tests showed were benign. But in July , Leanne began to complain of having chest pains and trouble breathing, which is when doctors found the five-centimetre mass on her lung. After visiting a specialist lung doctor at the Nuffield Health Centre in Derby, Leanne was diagnosed with stage four lung cancer. Doctors had already offered aiety of biopsy options to try to get to the bottom of what caused the growth, but some of these could have threatened her pregnancy and she was determined to give her baby the best possible chance. She even underwent painful investigative procedures, including chest drains and blood thinning injections, with minimal pain relief to minimise the effect on her unborn baby.  But since the birth of her son, Leannes cancer has progressed and spread rapidly to her liver, bones and brain. Jamie said Leanne had always beenvery active, enjoying running, swimming and gym classes, and had never smoked. He said: Id just say to everyone go and get checked out and be persistent, always get asecond opinion. I know not everyone has the option of private healthcare but I dread to think where we would be now without having had that second opinion. You always think its never going to happen to you, but no-one should be naive enough to think that. Jamie said he had been told that Leannes is the first case in the region where the cancer is known to have spread so quickly. He decided to start a JustGiving page not just to raise money for her treatment, but to raise awareness of her case and hopefully find someone who might be able to help. He said: It was something that I considered long and hard. We both had hard-working jobs and we lived a comfortable le, but now were not working and we need that extra treatment and to spread awareness of her story. Hopefully there is someone  out there who might be able to help us. Jamie, who is the captain and holder of the record number of appearances for Gresley FC, said he has a number of contacts in the football community and was hoping to get the page shared by some high profile names. But even he did not expect the overwhelming response that they got.   In less than  hours, they had smashed through their initial pound, target and by Tuesday they were heading rapidly towards a revised target of pound,, with more than,people having contributed. We cant thank people enough, he said. People have been incredible. Theres a lot of people supporting us and everyones been so generous. The money is set to go towards funding direct specialist treatment and other alternative homeopathic treatments to prolong Leannes le. Jamie said: Weve started some new treatment now which will keep her comfortable. Yes we want to prolong her le but ultimately we want to defy the odds, were praying for her every day and were remaining positive that she can and will beat this. Leanne has been simply overwhelmed by the well wishes, messages of support, flowers and gts that shes received. What shed love more than anything  in this world is to see her babies grow up and to be able to say that shes beating cancer. Anyone hoping to donate can do so on the JustGiving page.

story: NewsMum begs for safeof two kids taken by violent ex behind sword attackKarine Corner, from Coatbridge in North Lanarkshire, Scotland, claims Andreas Garalou, who was jailed in  for attacking a man with a sword, has run off with Naia, eight, and Noah, threeShareCommentsByMichael PringleBradley Jolly:,  NOV NewsKarine Corner has appealed for information after her children Naia and Noah vanished "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA desperate mum has made a heartbreaking plea for the safeof her two young children she claims were taken by their violent dad. story: NewsMum of Britains biggest family with  kids reveals incredible daily routineSue and Noel Radford welcomed baby Bonnie earlier this month, adding to their huge brood in Morecambe, LancashireShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video britains-largest-family-reveals-daily-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother-of- has revealed her hectic daily routine - which includes nine loads of washing EVERY DAY. Sue and Noel Radford welcomed baby Bonnie earlier this month, adding to their huge brood in Morecambe, Lancashire. The couple, who live in a  bedroom converted care home bought for pound,, said the entire family was smitten with the new arrival after Sue endured a -minute labour. Now, the -year-old mum has opened up about how she manages the day-to-day chores when it comes to caring for such a large family. The family go through a staggering nine washing loads every day, and  bottles of washing up liquid a month. They also use four toilet rolls every day, reports The Sun.  Feeding the family on around pound a week, Sue revealed how they usually eat large pasta or stew dishes - using meat from their local butcher and beg from the greengrocer.Sue said: For us the kitchen is the heart of our home and the kids just love to be involved with the cooking side of it. Sue added: The best thing about having a big family is you are never lonely and the kids are never lonely.   When it comes to ferrying their children around, Noel drives a minibus - which allows him to use bus lanes because it carries more than nine passengers. Six of the children are at the same primary school around  minutes away from the family home, and five attend the same secondary school. The three youngest children, Oscar, Caspar and Hallie stay at home with Sue - before Oscar visits nursery in the afternoon. Bath time for the youngsters starts at pm, with younger children in bed by around pm and older siblings sent to bed at . Sue and Noel said they are usually ready for a well-earned rest in bed by pm. Noel, , spoke about their newest arrival in a video created by Zanussi. He said: Just because weve got , that doesnt change our feelings towards having a new baby at all.   Its just as exciting now as it was with our very first. Its such a lovely moment when you bring a newborn home and the others are all lined up ready to hold her. But, despite their love of having children, Noel said they have decided to stop at  - and will not have any more children. Sue said: “We’ve both decided we don’t want any more. title: mum watching santa parade told
story: NewsMum watching Santa parade told child with autism cant use disabled viewing areaThe argument over where a seven-year-old girl could stand led to a massive row between parents at Princes Quay shopping centre in Hull, East YorkshireShareCommentsByJoanna LovellBradley Jolly:,  NOV NewsThe Santa Parade made its way through Hull on the weekend "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum watching a Santa parade was sickened after she was told her daughter with autism had no right to use the disabled . Marta, , told the woman not all disabilities are visible as they waited for Father Christmas to arrive at Princes Quay shopping centre in Hull, East Yorks., on the weekend.A dad had to calm the warring women, Hull Daily Mail says.Marta said: My daughter has autism and I put myself in the disabled area. I just found the area by coincidence. I was looking for a place and then saw the area and I thought why not   My daughter is OK with crowded places most of the time, but she rocks a lot to the sides and sometimes disturbs people by doing that, so I just thought lets go in there. I do not want to bother anyone or get advantage of anything but the place was there and she has the same right as any other disable person. title: mum who thought boys weeping
story: NewsMum who thought boys weeping eye was common cold shocked at cancer diagnosisHarri Cooke, four, from Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was diagnosed with Ewings Sarcoma - a rare type of bone cancer in JanuaryShareCommentsByElaine McCahillJess Grieveson-Smith:,  NOV NewsHarri Cookes mum Carly was left reeling when his weeping eye turned out to be cancer "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who thought her four-year-old boys weeping eye was from a common cold was left reeling when he was diagnosed with cancer. Harri Cooke, from Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was a happy and healthy tot before his mum, Carly, , noticed he had a weeping eye last September. After initially believing her son had a common cold that had caused conjunctivitis, it wasnt until Harris face began to swell that further tests were conducted and a deadly cancerous mass was discovered behind his nose. In January this year, Harri was diagnosed with Ewings Sarcoma - a rare type of bone cancer - and has since needed gruelling rounds of chemotherapy in a bid to shrink the tumour in his face as well as pioneering US treatment.   Harri is now in remission after nine months of treatment and his mum, Carly, is sharing their story to raise awareness. Carly, a self-employed massage therapist, said: Harri often had colds so at first I didnt think much of his weeping eye. The doctors agreed that it was likely to be a cold but as the weeks passed he was believed to have a blocked tear duct. It didnt seem to bother him, he was so happy all of the time. But when his face began to swell we were referred from our GP to an eye specialist. Once we arrived six doctors turned up, and they all seemed really worried. The NHS did everything they could but we just didnt realise how serious it was. Harris bone structure around his eye had changed, indicating the malicious mass that lay behind.   His type was so rare - we were in complete shock. You never think its going to be your child. It was six days later after Harris diagnosis that he started chemotherapy on February  this year. Carly, and husband James Cooke, , who works as mechanic, found themselves having to focus entirely on Harris treatment. His cancer would require treatment available only in America, as well as other NHS treatments. In order to give Harri the best possible odds, his cancer requires treatment with proton beam therapy - a type of radiotherapy that uses protons as opposed to x-rays. Carly added: I have another younger son called Josh, who is now  months, but we had to focus on Harri.  Family friends managed to raise us pound, for him to receive in order for him to receive proton beam therapy. The NHS fund the treatment and main expenses, but we couldnt have afforded for James to take  weeks off work. And despite everything he was still smiling, it was so hard watching him go through it, it was like torture. Harri endured  treatments in Florida, US - which continued every day under general anaesthetic for six weeks - combined with  rounds of chemotherapy. Thankfully it was all worthwhile and the youngster is now in remission but his parents now worry how his treatment will affect him in the long run. Carly said: I believe that only one percent of fundraising from big cancer charities goes specically to childrens cancer. The medication is so much harsher to children.   Harris treatments means that he could have growth issues, teeth problems and is more likely to have cancer later in le. Hes had to have over  blood transfusions to try and save his le. Carly is urging other parents to recognise the signs, however small, of this deadly illness, and help raise awareness of how a child can be affected. Carly said, Its so rare and unexpected that its hard to know what to look for. Blood supplies are currently depleted, and donors are needed for both blood and platelet transfusions. Charities like CLIC Sargent, a charity for children with cancer, are brilliant for helping families and informing them.

title: royal christmas traditions meghan markle
story: NewsThe Royal Christmas traditions that Meghan Markle will be taking part inThe Queen writes her Christmas cards in the summer and the Royals hand out silly gag gts...heres what  they get up to over the festive seasonShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV News "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChristmas is nearly here, when we’ll be kissing under mistletoe, pulling crackers, and pretending to like Brussels sprouts for a day. Butyou thought your family indulged in some strange traditions over the festive season, spare a thought for the royal family. It will be Meghan Markles second Christmas as a royal so theyll be no surprises this year. From handing out coal to poor people, to eating penny-sized sandwiches and handing out silly gag gts, here’s what the Royal family will be up to this Christmas... Presents from the Queen If you thought you organised Christmas well this year, you’ve got nothing on Her Maj, who asks her more than  members of staff what they want present they want her to buy them as early as March. The Queen gives a gt to everyone in the Royal household, as long as they have worked for her for more than a year. But they must choose what they get, to a value of   pound for the most junior staff, increasing year by year to a maximum of pound. Then, a week before Christmas, staff gather in the State Apartments, and one by one come forward to receive their gt from the Queen. They thank her, saying it’s exactly what the wanted without even opening it - of course, because they chose it themselves. The Queen buys her presents from just one shop, Harrods, and has been known to shut the entire department store for hours so she can wander round. These days, however, she does most of her shopping on the internet. By tradition, the Queen also gives one hundredweight of coal to “deserving and needy” people in Windsor before Christmas, although because of central heating the numbers have dipped from around  in the early days of her reign to less than  today.  Christmas cards in the Summer   The Queen writes her Christmas cards earlier than the rest of us too - normally during her stay in Balmoral during the summer. She and Prince Phillip send  Christmas cards to heads of state, leading politicians, Commonwealth leaders, friends and family. Phillip also sends another  of his own to the military, naval and civilian organisations with which he is associated. And recipients can tell how dear they are to her by the way she signs them. Close family members have theirs signed Lillibet - the Queen’s childhood nickname. Long-time friends such as Countess Mountbatten get theirs signed Elizabeth, without the R, while others like the Prime Minister, Lord Chancellor and the Speak of the House of Commons get a formal Elizabeth R. Those right down the bottom of her Christmas list don’t get a personally-signed card at all, just one rubber-stamped with the Queen’s signature.  Arriving at Sandringham  A week or so before Christmas, those family members who have been invited to spend the holiday with the Queen and Prince Philip are told by the Crown Equerry in what order they are to arrive at Sandringham House and at exactly what time. Royal protocol being what it is, it’s all worked out according to precedence and seniority, with the most junior and least important arriving first. Prince Charles, the Duchess of Cornwall, Prince William and Prince Harry are always the last to turn up. They then form a “welcoming” committee for the Queen and Prince Philip. Despite having her own Royal Train, the Queen usually makes the journey to Sandringham via public transport, and startling oblivious passengers on the Thamelink train to King’s Lynn has become a Christmas tradition in itself.  Princes’ football matchIn recent years, it has become tradition for Princes William and Harry to play a Christmas Eve football match alongside workers from the Sandringham Estate, with the Princes always on opposing sides. The brothers usually wear the socks of their favorite teams - Aston Villa for William and Arsenal for Harry, and they take it pretty seriously, with William even sustaining an ankle injury one year, and William once demanding that the ref give his brother a yellow card.  The Princes broke with tradition only once in  when they played on the same side, for the local Black Horse Inn pub, winning -.  Unwrapping gag gts The Royal family sit down at exactly pm on Christmas Eve open their presents in the red drawing room at Sandringham. During the afternoon family members creep down to secretly place their gts in the room, where trestle tables are laid out and sections marked off with table to show where each family member’s presents should be. The rule is that no-one should open their present until given permission by Philip, who supervises the proceedings, and that every present should be a cheap “joke gt”, and the cheaper the better.   Among memorable Christmas presents down the years are a ‘Ain’t le a bitch’ bath hat given to the Queen by Harry, a grow-your-own-girlfriend kit given to Harry by Kate, and a white leather toilet seat given by Princess Anne to Prince Charles, although he actually liked it so much he now takes it with him on overseas tours. Princess Diana once fell foul of the family cheap and cheerful motto when on her first Christmas at Sandringham as a newly-wed in  she gave a cashmere sweater to Princess Anne who, in , handed over a loo-roll holder. The next year she cracked it giving Fergie a leopard-print bath mat.  Jam-penny sandwichesWhile the Royal Family enjoy much of the same traditional food as the rest of us, some customs are still exclusively royal. Like “jam penny”, sandwiches cut into circles the size of an old English penny, which are served when the family gathers for afternoon tea in the white drawing room on Christmas Eve. They also enjoy scones cut into the size and shape of a -pence piece. Later on, the family meet up again for a black tie dinner and drinks, where each royal has their own traditional tipple. The Queen favours a cocktail call the Zaza, made from Dubonnet and gin, Prince Charles prefers cherry brandy, while William and Harry both enjoy a pint of Sandringham cider, made from apple trees planted by the Queen’s father King George VI. During the dinner the Queen is known to read out corny jokes from the Christmas crackers. Later the family play charades until midnight, with nobody permitted to go to bed until Her Majesty retires.  Two church servicesOn Christmas Day the family go to church twice. First, the family attends a private service at am, when the Queen receives Holy Communion from her chaplain. Then she leads the Royal family to St Mary Magdalene Church for the traditional Christmas Day service at am. All the family walk to church except the Queen, who is driven. When the collection plate is passed round, Her Majesty’s equerry, who sits in the pew immediately behind her, hands her a pound note - the only time in the year the Queen uses money.  Whiskey with the chef  Just like most of the rest of the country, the Royal family will stuff themselves full with a traditional Christmas dinner. Theirs starts at .pm with a starter of salad with shrimp or lobster, followed by roasted turkey with traditional sides like parsnips, Brussels sprouts and carrots, then Christmas pudding with brandy butter for dessert. Menus are all in French and the family eat from blue and white Copeland dinner service and drink from crystal stemware engraved with EIIR. As is tradition, just before the family tuck in, the senior chef goes into the dining room and carves the rib roast of turkey, after which the Queen presents him with a glass of whiskey and they toast - the only time in the year that the chef joins the royals in the dining room.  After lunch the family will watch the Queen’s annual address to the nation, before adjourning to the Saloon, where the Queen’s favourite jigsaw puzzles are laid out. There are actually five Christmas dinners served at dferent times at Sandringham - one for junior staff at am, then for the senior footmen an hour later. After the Royal family’s dinner at .pm, the junior kitchen staff have theirs at .pm, and the royal chef is last to have his lunch at pm. Christmas goes on until February The Queen and Prince Philip stay at Sandringham until early February, in memory of Her Majestys late dad George VI, who died at the estate on February , . Not in the least superstitious, the Queen insists on the Christmas decorations remaining up until she leaves.

story: NewsThanksgiving traditions explained as Americans celebrate annual holidayIts a national holiday in the USA, but what are the traditions around this famous celebration ShareCommentsByAndrew SnellHomepage Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video look-history-behind-american-national-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAmericans are celebrating Thanksgiving this week, getting together with their families and enjoying a huge turkey dinner. The holiday celebrates the fruits of the harvest, and has been celebrated in America since the s - before the USA even existed as a country. Today it is a national holiday in the US, celebrated every year on the fourth Thursday in November. Workers are given the day off - and often the following day too so they can enjoy a four-day weekend. But while Brits may have seen the celebrations on TV or films, they might not know all the traditions that go along with this big day. So heres the big Thanksgiving traditions to be aware of...  The food A hearty meal is one of the most important Thanksgiving traditions for most Americans. The central element of a traditional meal is usually a huge roast turkey. Alongside this are sides like mashed potato, stuffing, cranberry sauce and vegetables. Americans also often talk about eating yams. Yams are a starchy root vegetable grown in the Carribean. But Americans usually mean sweet potatoes instead. The meal is often rounded off with a pumpkin pie.  Pardoning the turkey As a day of the year where people eat a lot of meat, it cant be a good time to be a turkey. So each year the US President officially pardons a turkey, and it is sent to live on a farm rather than heading for the dinner table. The odd tradition dates back to , when President Lincolns son Tad asked him to spare the le of the turkey bought home for dinner. The tradition became more formalised under the George H W Bush White House. This year Donald Trump pardoned two turkeys, named Peas and Carrot.  The parades Many cities in the US host massive parades as part of the Thanksgiving Day celebrations. The biggest and most famous is the Macys parade in New York, which attracts thousands of spectators to the streets of Manhattan. The three-hour spectacle features floats, costumes and giant helium balloons of famous cartoon characters.  The sports American Football games are a huge part of the long Thanksgiving weekend, and NFL and college teams have played on Thanksgiving practically since the games invention. It is one of the biggest days in the football calendar, and this year is no exception. The three NFL games on Thanksgiving day this year are all big league rivalries: Chicago Bears vs Detroit Lions - :pm GMTWashington Redskins vs Dallas Cowboys - :pm GMTAtlanta Falcons vs New Orleans Saints - :am GMT Black Friday The day after Thanksgiving every year is one of the busiest shopping days of the year. People take advantage of their day off and massive sales at stores to make a start on their Christmas shopping. Black Friday has become notorious for scenes of violence as mobs of customers fight over discount TVs.  The shopping tradition has now spread around the world, as stores in other countries try to cash in on the huge numbers of shoppers desperate for a bargain. In the UK, theres all sorts of deals to be found in the annual sales.

title: fans backing can be points in the bag for dundee united
story: There are few managers operating in the Championship right now who know better than Robbie Neilson just how powerful fans can be.As a player, he played more than two thirds of his  plus games for Hearts, whose supporters, arguably, create the best atmosphere of any club outside of the Old Firm when their team is playing in front of them at Tynecastle.And Robbie, of course, experienced more of what the Jambos fans have to offer when he successfully managed them for two-and-a-half years.Those spells in Edinburgh, in particular, taught him the backing of a passionate support can be worth points to a team.And he believes that can prove the case now he’s in charge at Dundee United.Since taking over from Csaba Laszlo at Tannadice last month, Robbie has mentioned the quality of the backing Arabs have given his rejuvenated team on several occasions.And he firmly believes they’ve more than played their part in an impressive unbeaten run of four wins and a draw that has seen the Tangerines re-emerge as serious promotion contenders from the second tier.On Tuesday night, however, it could be a case of ided loyalties for some Arabs, simply because United will be facing Alloa in a re-arranged league outing at the same time as Scotland face what could be a vital Nations League clash with Israel at Hampden.Having been blown away by the backing so far, the manager suspects it will be a case of club before country for most.“I’m definitely looking for a big turnout,” he said.“If there are any more pull-outs, my problem could be a few players might get called up for the Scotland squad!”Jokes aside, he does believe most Arabs will be in their usual seats at Tannadice and providing the kind of backing that’s become the envy of the rest of the second tier.“You have that Scotland game but the fans have been brilliant since I came in,” he said.“We took nearly , fans up to Ross County last weekend and we took , to Dunfermline the other week as well.“We’ve had great backing at home as well and, hopefully, they will turn up in numbers.“I understand midweek football means it’s always dficult for fans to make the journey.“We hope we can prove to them thatthey come along we’ll try to entertain and try to get a result.”As good as the backing so far has been, the manager does stress it remains down to his team to always make sure the supporters in the stands are given something to shout about.“The fans can make a massive dference but the initial stage will come from the players because the players, in the first  minutes of the game, have to set the tone,” he said.“They have to set the intensity and they have to get the fans off their seats.“If we can do that it reciprocates from the fans and we start putting pressure on teams and that’s what we need.”And that experience of playing with Hearts tells himthe support is on top form, at times it can mean points are picked up before a ball is even kicked.“I’ve played in venues where teams have come and you knew, because of the atmosphere and intensity, the game was done in the warm-up,” he said.“You knew you were going to win the game because the opposition couldn’t handle the atmosphere.“We need the supporters to try to give us that and we know they can.”

title: no parking bus at hibees for dundee
story: Jim McIntyre has no plans to park the bus this coming weekend as his Dundee side travel to free-scoring Hibs in the Premiership.The Dark Blues have the leakiest defence in the ision while the Hibees have notched  in five league matches at Easter Road ahead of their clash on Saturday.The Dens gaffer is under no illusions how tough it will be against Neil Lennon’s side, though he’s seen encouragement from his side over the past couple of matches.And he’s planning to put their opponents “under pressure” as his side aim for a much-needed result.He said: “Things were taken on from the Motherwell game and things were more positive with the St Mirren performance and it’s about trying to turn small margins into points.“We know we are facing a top side in Hibs who have done a fantastic job this season, are an exciting team to watch and have a lot of attacking threat but we have to go there and put them under pressure.”Of late, however, the Hibees haven’t won in their last four – but that recent form won’t change how Dundee prepare.“You are going to have peaks and troughs through any season but I’m sure them being at home Lenny will have them fired up,” added Jim.“We know they have good players and will be looking to take maximum points but from our own end the encouraging signs have been there and we want to try to build on the St Mirren result.“The boys clearly know how I work now after a month. The players have been great, they’ve worked extremely hard. You don’t want continuous breaks on Saturdays but we are coming into a busy period in December.”

title: revealed arsenal watched dundee prospect kerr waddell
story: Dundee kid Kerr Waddell was watched by English Premier League giants Arsenal during the summer.And the -year-old’s progress continues to be monitored by a string of clubs from south of the border.Wednesday saw Waddell extend his loan at Championship outfit Morton until the end of the season, a move that will free him up to play in the Scottish Cup as well as league matches.Waddell made his temporary switch to Greenock, at first on a six-month deal, in early July but initially it had been pencilled in for a few weeks earlier so he could join the Ton at the start of their pre-season training programme.The loan was delayed, however, and he played in the Dark Blues opening build up game at Brechin City at the end of June, when he was watched by Gunners scouts.That was with a view to adding him to their U  squad and although the spying mission did not lead to an offer being tabled, Arsenal and others down south have been keeping tabs on his progress at Morton.New Dundee boss Jim McIntyre has also had reports on him but with good options available in defence, he’s decided the player’s development will be best served by remaining at Morton until the end of the season.Waddell broke into the first team at Dens early last season and got the goals that earned a vital win over Hearts a year past September.Injury and the arrival of experienced central defensive pair Genseric Kusunga and Steven Caulker in the early weeks of this year, saw his appearances in the second half of the campaign dry up.At Morton he’s made  appearances so far this term.The Dens gaffer has said he’s keeping an eye on all his players out on loan to see what they might add to the first-team should they be recalled in January.He said: “We send people to go and watch them so we are getting proper feedback.“Ideally, going forward I would like a position created for the loan players, somebody who keeps an eye on them so we are getting reports on each game.“The possibility is there for bringing them back but they need to be doing well where they are.”n Glen Kamara played  minutes for Finland last night in their - Nations League loss in Greece.

title: va dundee announces future looking exhibitions for 2019 and 2020
story: VA Dundee has revealed its  international exhibition programme. vw, px"  Videogames, robots and the future of design will be explored by  Scotland’s first design museum.The exhibitions will celebrate the design and culture of contemporary videogames with the VA’s spectacular show Videogames: Design Play Disrupt, which will run from April  to September  .A VA Dundee statement said: #This is the first exhibition to fully consider the complexity of videogames as one of the most important design fields of our time.#Today there are an estimated . billion people who play videogames worldwide, from commuters playing on mobile phones to eSports professionals watched by tens of thousands of spectators.# vw, px"  The exhibition focuses on videogames designed and developed since the mid-s when major technological advancements transformed the way games are designed, discussed and played.From multi-million-dollar blockbuster titles to smaller independent games and the work of DIY artists from a hacker maker culture, the exhibition explores current international debates as well as the creative contributions made to game culture by the players themselves.Alongside the exhibition there will be a ied programme of events, talks, commissions and learning workshops inspired by videogame design that will reflect the local expertise of Scottish designers, companies and academics in the field.As part of this programme, VA Dundee is today calling on designers with a link to Scotland to submit a proposal for a digital game commission that explores character development and the idea of self in videogames.The appointed designer will be chosen by a  including experts from the Dundee videogame industry and will develop their game for VA Dundee’s website. The commission will be supported by InGAME, an Abertay University-led games innovation partnership. vw, px"  vw, px"  vw, px"  vw, px"  vw, px"  VA Dundee will then go on to examine the current boom in robotics with the exhibition Hello, Robot. Design between Human and Machine which will run from November   to February  .#This groundbreaking exhibition investigates the science and fiction of robots and looks at how they are changing the world we live in,# added the statement.#Posing a series of provocative questions, it explores how popular culture has shaped our perception of robots and articial humans, the impact this technology has had on industry and the increasing blurring of the boundaries between human and machine.#The exhibition shows the startling impact robots have already had on our world from fashion to architecture and even social care. Hello, Robot. Design between Human and Machine gives a comprehensive look at the current state of robotics and provides a fascinating vision of the future.#VA Dundee is also working with Glasgow-based designer Gabriella Marcella, the founder of RISOTTO, whose work will be the focus of a new exhibition in the museum’s Michelin Design Gallery.Gabriella will create an installation exploring the principles of learning through play and how creativity can be supported by the defining constraints of material and colour.Philip Long, Director of VA Dundee, said: “Through an eclectic programme, VA Dundee aims to inspire people and provoke discussion about the role of design in everyone’s lives.“Videogames: Design Play Disrupt and Hello, Robot. Design between Human and Machine are both hugely important exhibitions looking at how designers and technology are shaping human experience, both for the better and in ways we find challenging.“Dundee is a city at the forefront of videogame design and innovation and we are very much looking forward to working with partners and creative collaborators to deliver a unique programme to accompany our next show.“We are also delighted to be working with the highly talented Gabriella Marcella, the founder of RISOTTO, who is creating a dynamic and interactive exhibition investigating how we can learn through play.”Sophie McKinlay, Director of Programme at VA Dundee, said: “Our role as a new design museum is to present an exciting and wide-ranging exploration of the world of design through our programme.“Design shapes every aspect of our lives, and through these two major international exhibitions we will look at contemporary practice in videogames and the future impact of robots on every aspect of our lives.”Professor Gregor White, head of Abertay University’s School of Design and Informatics, said: “Dundee is a world-renowned centre for computer games education and a melting pot of Scottish, UK and international games talent so I am delighted that videogames will be the focus of the next major exhibition at VA Dundee.“I’m particularly excited to be working with the team at VA Dundee to commission a new videogame offering designers a great opportunity to get involved and showcase their creative talent.”VA Dundee opened on September  with the exhibition Ocean Liners: Speed and Style. The new museum will feature VA exhibitions, exhibitions from international partner venues, as well as curating its own exhibitions in future.Videogames: Design Play Disrupt is on show at VA South Kensington until  February. Hello, Robot. Design between Human and Machine, developed by Vitra Design Museum, has never been shown in the UK before.

title: win against alloa could see dundee united eat into ayrs lead
story: Dundee United go into today’s re-arranged Championship clash with Alloa knowing they can eat into the gap at the top of the table.The weekend saw leaders Ayr United slip up when they were held at home by Morton.It means three points for the Tangerines today will mean a deficit that stood at eight when gaffer Robbie Neilson took over last month would be down to just three.And it would leave them able to wipe out the Honest Men’s advantage when the pair meet at Tannadice next week, though they could still trail Ross County, who currently lie second.Robbie has stressed he and his players will be looking no further forward than today’s outing but already the meeting with Ayr on Friday week is shaping up to be one of the most important games of the season so far.United remain hopeful of having skipper Fraser Fyvie, centre-half Frederic Frans and full-back Callum Booth available for today.They were all stepping up their work in training over the weekend after injury problems.If they’ve suffered no reactions, they’ll be in the squad.And in the case of Frans and Booth, both of whom have missed games, the manager has admitted that would give him a nice selection headache.“They have been doing well in the team but so have the players who’ve taken over from them while they were injured,” said Robbie.The reserves are not in action this week and don’t have another competitive fixture until they’re due to face Celtic in a league game early next month.
